description: High blood pressure with no identifiable secondary cause (ICD-10: I10). It accounts for 90-95% of all hypertension cases and causes progressive strain on the heart and arteries.

symptoms.details: Most patients have no specific symptoms until complications arise ('The Silent Killer').
A dull headache in the back of the head, typically upon waking, occurring in severe cases.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: 24-hour monitoring to rule out 'white coat hypertension' and confirm persistent elevation.
Examination of the eyes to check for hypertensive retinopathy (blood vessel damage).

treatments_and_cures.details: First-line medication to help the kidneys remove excess sodium and water.
Relaxes blood vessels by blocking the formation of angiotensin II.

description: Chest pain that occurs at rest or with minimal exertion (ICD-10: I20.0). Unlike stable angina, it is unpredictable and signals a high risk of an impending heart attack.

symptoms.details: Pain or pressure that occurs without physical exertion and may last longer than 10-20 minutes.
Symptoms may not resolve completely with standard sublingual medication.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes the severity of artery narrowing to determine if stenting is needed.
May show ST-segment depression or T-wave inversion, but no ST elevation.

treatments_and_cures.details: Mechanical widening of the narrowed artery to restore blood flow.
Aspirin plus a P2Y12 inhibitor (e.g., Clopidogrel) to prevent clot formation.

description: A type of heart attack where the coronary artery is partially blocked, causing heart muscle damage without the classic ST-segment elevation on ECG (ICD-10: I21.4).

symptoms.details: Crushing sensation behind the breastbone.
Sudden, heavy sweating ('cold sweat').

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Detects elevated cardiac enzymes indicating heart muscle necrosis.
Shows ST depression or T-wave inversion (distinguishing it from STEMI).

treatments_and_cures.details: Prevents the clot from growing while awaiting angiography.
Angiography within 24-48 hours to identify and treat the blockage.

description: A blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by blood clots that travel from the legs (DVT) (ICD-10: I26). It puts immense strain on the right side of the heart.

symptoms.details: Rapid onset of shortness of breath without prior exertion.
Sharp chest pain that worsens when breathing in deeply.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Uses contrast dye to visualize the filling defect (clot) in the lung arteries.
Measures a substance released when a clot breaks up; high negative predictive value.

treatments_and_cures.details: Blood thinners that prevent the clot from getting bigger and prevent new clots.
Used only in massive PE with shock to dissolve the clot rapidly.

description: Narrowing of the mitral valve opening that blocks blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle (ICD-10: I05.0). The most common cause is Rheumatic Fever.

symptoms.details: Breathlessness due to fluid backing up into the lungs.
Coughing up blood due to ruptured bronchial veins from high pressure.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes the valve 'hockey stick' appearance and measures the gradient/area.

treatments_and_cures.details: A balloon catheter is used to force the stiff valve open.
Reduces lung congestion and swelling.

description: A condition where the heart's ability to pump blood is decreased because the left ventricle is enlarged and weakened (ICD-10: I42.0).

symptoms.details: Shortness of breath when lying flat.
Swelling in legs and ankles.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows dilated chambers and reduced systolic function (low EF).
Can identify tissue scarring (fibrosis) and specific causes like sarcoidosis.

treatments_and_cures.details: Pillar therapy to reduce cardiac workload and prevent remodeling.
The final option for end-stage failure refractory to medication.

description: A genetic disease where the heart muscle (myocardium) becomes abnormally thick (hypertrophied), making it harder for the heart to pump blood (ICD-10: I42.1).

symptoms.details: Fainting during physical activity due to outflow obstruction.
Sensation of rapid heartbeats often caused by associated arrhythmias.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Measures wall thickness (usually septum > 15mm) and outflow gradient.
Identifies mutations in sarcomere genes (e.g., MYH7, MYBPC3).

treatments_and_cures.details: Relaxes the heart muscle, allowing better filling and reducing obstruction.
Surgical removal of the thickened muscle.

description: Inflammation of the pericardium (the sac surrounding the heart) (ICD-10: I30). It is often idiopathic or viral in origin.

symptoms.details: Sharp pain that worsens when lying flat and improves when leaning forward.
A scratching sound heard through a stethoscope.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression.

treatments_and_cures.details: High-dose anti-inflammatories are the mainstay of treatment.
Added to NSAIDs to prevent recurrence of the inflammation.

description: An infection of the endocardium, usually involving the heart valves (ICD-10: I33). Bacteria enter the bloodstream and attach to damaged portions of the heart.

symptoms.details: Unexplained fever lasting days or weeks.
Painless red spots on the palms or soles.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Superior to TTE for visualizing 'vegetations' (bacterial clumps) on valves.
Requires multiple sets to identify the specific bacteria causing the infection.

treatments_and_cures.details: High-dose intravenous antibiotics for 4-6 weeks.
Required if the infection destroys the valve or causes heart failure.

description: A type of abnormal heart rhythm that occurs in the atria of the heart (ICD-10: I48.3). It is similar to AFib but the rhythm is organized and regular (sawtooth pattern).

symptoms.details: Pulse is often fast and steady (e.g., 150 bpm).
Tiredness due to inefficient pumping.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows characteristic 'sawtooth' flutter waves (F-waves).

treatments_and_cures.details: Cauterizing the specific electrical circuit (isthmus) causing the flutter; high success rate.
Used to lower the heart rate if ablation is not performed.

description: An enlargement of the aorta, the main blood vessel that delivers blood to the body, at the level of the abdomen (ICD-10: I71.4). If it bursts, it causes life-threatening internal bleeding.

symptoms.details: A feeling of a heartbeat near the navel.
Constant, gnawing pain in the abdomen or side of the back.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: The primary screening tool to measure the diameter of the aorta (normal is < 3cm).
Used for surgical planning to visualize the exact anatomy and extent of the aneurysm.

treatments_and_cures.details: Minimally invasive placement of a stent-graft inside the aneurysm to reinforce the wall.
For small aneurysms (< 5.0 cm), monitoring growth rate is the standard of care.

description: A life-threatening condition where the inner layer of the aorta tears, causing blood to rush between the layers and separate (dissect) them (ICD-10: I71.0). Type A involves the ascending aorta.

symptoms.details: Sudden, severe pain described as 'ripping' or 'tearing' radiating to the back (between shoulder blades).
Difference in blood pressure or pulse strength between the left and right arms.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes the 'intimal flap' (the tear) and the false lumen created by the blood flow.
Can be used in unstable patients who cannot be moved to a CT scanner.

treatments_and_cures.details: Replacing the damaged section of the aorta with a synthetic tube graft. Immediate surgery is required for survival.
Used immediately to lower heart rate and blood pressure to prevent the tear from spreading.

description: A blood clot (thrombus) forms in a deep vein, usually in the legs (ICD-10: I82.4). The major risk is the clot breaking loose and traveling to the lungs (PE).

symptoms.details: Swelling in just one leg, often starting at the calf.
Cramping pain that worsens when bending the foot upward (Homan's sign).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes the vein and checks for compressibility (a clot prevents the vein from collapsing).
Blood test used to rule out DVT in low-risk patients.

treatments_and_cures.details: Medication to prevent the clot from growing and allow the body to dissolve it over time.
Helps reduce swelling and prevent Post-Thrombotic Syndrome.

description: Narrowing of the arteries in the limbs, usually the legs, due to atherosclerosis (plaque buildup) (ICD-10: I73.9). It reduces blood flow to muscles.

symptoms.details: Pain or cramping in the legs (calves) triggered by walking and relieved by rest.
Diminished or absent pulses in the feet (dorsalis pedis).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Compares blood pressure in the ankle to the arm. An index < 0.90 indicates PAD.
Imaging to locate the exact site of the blockage for potential intervention.

treatments_and_cures.details: Medication that dilates arteries and improves walking distance.
Surgery to route blood around the blocked artery or open it with a balloon.

description: Complete heart block where no electrical signals from the atria reach the ventricles (ICD-10: I44.2). The ventricles beat at their own very slow 'escape' rate.

symptoms.details: Heart rate is dangerously slow (e.g., 30-40 bpm).
Sudden loss of consciousness due to insufficient blood flow to the brain.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows P waves (atria) and QRS complexes (ventricles) beating completely independently (AV dissociation).

treatments_and_cures.details: Implanted device to electrically stimulate the heart ventricles at a normal rate. Required for survival.
Temporary measures to increase heart rate in an emergency setting.

description: A congenital condition involving an extra electrical pathway (Bundle of Kent) between the atria and ventricles, causing rapid heartbeats (ICD-10: I45.6).

symptoms.details: Sudden episodes of very rapid heart rate.
Lightheadedness during episodes of tachycardia.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows a 'Delta wave' (slurred upstroke of QRS) and a short PR interval.
Maps the electrical system to locate the exact position of the accessory pathway.

treatments_and_cures.details: Burning or freezing the extra pathway to permanently stop the abnormal signals.
Medications like Procainamide to suppress the abnormal rhythm (AV nodal blockers like Adenosine are often contraindicated).

description: A heart rhythm disorder that can cause fast, chaotic heartbeats (ICD-10: I45.81). It involves delayed repolarization of the heart, seen as a long QT interval on ECG.

symptoms.details: Often triggered by exercise, swimming, or emotional stress.
Caused by the brain not getting enough oxygen during an arrhythmia episode.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Measures the QTc interval. > 480ms is generally considered diagnostic.
Identifies mutations in ion channel genes (KCNQ1, KCNH2, SCN5A).

treatments_and_cures.details: Blunts the adrenaline response that triggers the arrhythmia.
Implated in high-risk patients to shock the heart back to rhythm if cardiac arrest occurs.

description: A group of heart rhythm problems in which the sinus node (the heart's natural pacemaker) doesn't work properly (ICD-10: I49.5). It often manifests as alternating slow and fast rhythms (Tachy-Brady syndrome).

symptoms.details: Unusually slow heartbeat while awake.
Chronic tiredness due to inadequate heart rate response to activity.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: 24-48 hour recording to catch episodes of sinus pauses or bradycardia.

treatments_and_cures.details: The standard treatment to prevent the heart from beating too slowly.
Stopping any drugs (like beta blockers) that might be worsening the slow heart rate.

description: A condition where the aortic valve doesn't close tightly, allowing blood to leak backward from the aorta into the left ventricle (ICD-10: I35.1).

symptoms.details: A forceful pulse that can be seen or felt in the neck (Corrigan's pulse).
Shortness of breath during exercise as the heart fails to pump efficiently.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes the backflow (regurgitant jet) and measures the severity.

treatments_and_cures.details: Surgery to replace the leaky valve is indicated when symptoms appear or the heart enlarges.
Reduces the pressure the heart has to pump against, reducing the backward leak.

description: A problem with blood flow to the fingers (and sometimes toes, ears, nose) in response to cold or stress (ICD-10: I73.0). The small arteries narrow appropriately (vasospasm).

symptoms.details: Fingers turn white (ischemia), then blue (hypoxia), then red (reperfusion).
Loss of sensation in the affected digits during the attack.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Measuring temperature recovery of fingers after immersion in ice water.
Microscopic exam of the nail bed to distinguish primary Raynaud's from secondary (caused by autoimmune disease).

treatments_and_cures.details: Relaxes the small blood vessels to prevent spasms.
Keeping hands warm (gloves) and avoiding smoking.

description: A 'hole in the heart' between the two upper chambers (atria) present at birth (ICD-10: Q21.1). Oxygen-rich blood leaks from the left side to the right side, increasing blood flow to the lungs.

symptoms.details: A soft 'whooshing' sound heard between heartbeats, often the only sign in children.
Increased blood flow to the lungs makes them more susceptible to infection.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes the hole; bubbles injected into a vein are seen crossing from right to left atrium.

treatments_and_cures.details: A plug-like device (e.g., Amplatzer) is inserted via catheter to seal the hole.
Small defects often close on their own during childhood and require no treatment.

description: A hole in the wall separating the two lower chambers (ventricles) of the heart (ICD-10: Q21.0). It is the most common congenital heart defect.

symptoms.details: Infants may tire easily during feeding and fail to gain weight.
A distinctive, harsh noise heard through a stethoscope.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Determines the size and location of the defect to assess the need for surgery.

treatments_and_cures.details: Open-heart surgery to sew a patch over the hole; usually done in infancy for large defects.
Helps reduce fluid retention in the lungs caused by the extra blood flow.

description: A complex condition consisting of four defects: VSD, Pulmonary Stenosis, Right Ventricular Hypertrophy, and Overriding Aorta (ICD-10: Q21.3). It causes oxygen-poor blood to flow out to the body.

symptoms.details: Blue tint to the skin, lips, and fingernails because of low oxygen levels.
Sudden episodes of deep blue skin after crying or feeding.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Can diagnose the condition before the baby is born.
Measures pressure and oxygen levels in the heart chambers prior to surgery.

treatments_and_cures.details: Open-heart surgery to patch the VSD and widen the pulmonary valve, usually done in the first year of life.

description: A narrowing of the aorta, usually just after the arteries branch off to the head and arms (ICD-10: Q25.1). The heart must pump harder to force blood through the narrow part.

symptoms.details: High blood pressure in the arms but low blood pressure in the legs.
Reduced blood flow to the lower body.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Provides detailed 3D imaging of the aortic arch anatomy.

treatments_and_cures.details: Expanding the narrowed section using a balloon catheter.
Surgery to remove the narrowed segment and reconnect the ends.

description: A persistent opening between the two major blood vessels leading from the heart (aorta and pulmonary artery) (ICD-10: Q25.0). This opening normally closes shortly after birth.

symptoms.details: A continuous, machine-like heart sound.
Tachypnea caused by lung congestion.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Confirms the flow of blood from the aorta into the pulmonary artery.

treatments_and_cures.details: NSAIDs can stimulate the vessel to close in premature infants.
Using a catheter to place a coil or plug to seal the opening in older children.

description: Inflammation of the heart muscle (myocardium), most often caused by a viral infection (e.g., Coxsackie, COVID-19) (ICD-10: I40). It can weaken the heart and cause arrhythmias.

symptoms.details: Can mimic a heart attack due to inflammation.
Extreme tiredness often following a recent flu-like illness.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows tissue edema (swelling) and late gadolinium enhancement (scarring).
Taking a tissue sample; used only in severe/unclear cases as it is invasive.

treatments_and_cures.details: Avoiding athletic activity for 3-6 months is critical to prevent sudden cardiac death.
Beta blockers and ACE inhibitors used temporarily to support the pump function.

description: Permanent damage to the heart valves caused by rheumatic fever, which is an autoimmune reaction to an untreated strep throat infection (ICD-10: I05-I09).

symptoms.details: Caused by valve damage (stenosis or regurgitation) developing years after the infection.
History of migratory arthritis during the initial acute fever phase.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows characteristic valve thickening and fusion (especially the mitral valve).
Blood test confirming recent streptococcal infection (useful in acute phase).

treatments_and_cures.details: Long-term monthly antibiotic injections (sometimes for years) to prevent recurrent Strep infections.
Repair or replacement of the damaged valves.

description: A temporary heart condition brought on by extreme stress or grief ('Broken Heart Syndrome') (ICD-10: I42.8). The left ventricle balloons out and weakens.

symptoms.details: Indistinguishable from a heart attack.
Shortness of breath due to acute heart failure.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows the characteristic 'octopus pot' shape of the ventricle and clean coronary arteries (no blockage).

treatments_and_cures.details: Used to reduce workload on the heart while it recovers naturally (usually within weeks).
Avoiding emotional triggers to prevent recurrence.

description: A condition where the valve between the two right heart chambers doesn't close properly, causing blood to leak backward into the right atrium (ICD-10: I07.1).

symptoms.details: Jugular venous distension with a visible pulse wave.
Fluid accumulation in the abdomen due to back pressure in the venous system.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Measures the severity of the leak and the pressure in the pulmonary artery.

treatments_and_cures.details: Reduces fluid buildup in the body.
Surgical tightening of the valve ring, often done during other heart surgeries.

description: A narrowing of the pulmonary valve, obstructing blood flow from the right ventricle to the lungs (ICD-10: Q22.1).

symptoms.details: Reduced exercise tolerance.
A murmur heard at the upper left sternal border.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Measures the pressure gradient across the valve to determine severity.

treatments_and_cures.details: The treatment of choice; a balloon is inflated to stretch the valve open.

description: High blood pressure specifically in the arteries of the lungs (ICD-10: I27.0). The small arteries in the lungs narrow, forcing the right side of the heart to work harder, eventually leading to failure.

symptoms.details: Shortness of breath that progressively worsens with activity.
Fainting episodes caused by the inability of the heart to increase blood flow during exertion.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Directly measures the pressure in the pulmonary arteries (mPAP > 20 mmHg confirms diagnosis).
Estimates pulmonary pressures and shows right ventricular enlargement.

treatments_and_cures.details: Relaxes the blood vessels in the lungs to lower pressure.
Blocks substances that cause blood vessels to constrict.

description: Failure of the right side of the heart caused by long-term high blood pressure in the pulmonary arteries and right ventricle (ICD-10: I27.9). It is usually a complication of chronic lung diseases like COPD.

symptoms.details: Significant swelling in legs and feet due to right-sided failure.
Bulging neck veins indicating high venous pressure.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Assesses the size and function of the right ventricle.

treatments_and_cures.details: Relieves the low oxygen levels that cause the pulmonary arteries to constrict.
Reduces fluid overload.

description: Episodes of rapid heart rate (160-220 bpm) that start and stop suddenly, originating above the ventricles (ICD-10: I47.1).

symptoms.details: Sensation of the heart racing or pounding in the chest or throat.
Sudden feeling of panic accompanying the rapid rate.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows a narrow complex tachycardia with hidden or abnormal P-waves.

treatments_and_cures.details: Techniques like bearing down (Valsalva) or splashing cold water on the face to slow the heart.
IV medication that briefly blocks the AV node to 'reset' the rhythm.

description: A fast, abnormal heart rhythm starting in the lower chambers (ventricles) (ICD-10: I47.2). It is potentially life-threatening as it can degrade into Ventricular Fibrillation.

symptoms.details: Caused by the heart beating too fast to fill properly, reducing output.
Loss of consciousness is common if the rhythm is sustained.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows a wide complex tachycardia (QRS > 120ms).

treatments_and_cures.details: Electric shock to restore normal rhythm in unstable patients.
Antiarrhythmic drug used to stabilize the rhythm.

description: Extra heartbeats that begin in one of the ventricles (ICD-10: I49.3). These disrupt the regular heart rhythm and often cause a 'skipping' sensation.

symptoms.details: Feeling a pause followed by a strong thud (the post-extrasystolic beat).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Quantifies the 'burden' (percentage) of PVCs over a 24-hour period.

treatments_and_cures.details: Used if symptoms are bothersome to suppress the extra beats.
In healthy hearts, no treatment is needed as PVCs are benign.

description: A rare form of heart muscle disease where the ventricles become stiff and rigid, but not thickened (ICD-10: I42.5). The heart cannot relax to fill with blood.

symptoms.details: Shortness of breath due to high filling pressures backing up into lungs.
Inability to increase cardiac output during activity.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Can differentiate restriction from constriction and identify infiltration (e.g., Amyloidosis).
Definitive test to find the cause (e.g., amyloid proteins, iron overload).

treatments_and_cures.details: Cautious use to reduce congestion without lowering filling pressure too much.
Chemotherapy for Amyloidosis or Chelation for Hemochromatosis.

description: A medical emergency where fluid or blood accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and preventing it from filling (ICD-10: I31.4).

symptoms.details: Low blood pressure, distended neck veins, and distant (muffled) heart sounds.
Rapid heart rate as the body tries to compensate for low output.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows pericardial effusion with collapse of the right atrium/ventricle during diastole.

treatments_and_cures.details: Needle drainage of the fluid from the sac to relieve pressure immediately.

description: Chest pain caused by a spasm of the coronary arteries rather than a blockage (ICD-10: I20.1). It typically occurs at rest, often in the early morning.

symptoms.details: Severe pain occurring at the same time each day, usually at rest.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Provocative test during angiography to induce the spasm and confirm diagnosis.
Shows transient ST-segment elevation during pain that resolves when pain stops.

treatments_and_cures.details: Potent vasodilators that prevent the spasms from occurring.
Effective for stopping an acute attack.

description: The most common primary heart tumor (benign), usually found in the left atrium (ICD-10: D15.1). It can obstruct blood flow or break off causing strokes.

symptoms.details: Breathing difficulty that changes when standing up or lying down (tumor moves).
Fever and weight loss due to systemic inflammation caused by the tumor.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes a mobile mass attached to the atrial septum.

treatments_and_cures.details: Open heart surgery to remove the tumor is curative.

description: A rare genetic disorder of the heart's electrical system that increases the risk of abnormal heart rhythms and sudden cardiac death (ICD-10: I49.8).

symptoms.details: Fainting without warning.
Gasping or labored breathing during sleep.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows characteristic 'coved' ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V3 (Type 1 pattern).
Administering sodium channel blockers (like Ajmaline) to unmask the ECG pattern.

treatments_and_cures.details: The only proven therapy to prevent sudden death.
Fevers and certain medications can trigger the fatal arrhythmia.

description: An acute condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body (ICD-10: M30.3). It most commonly affects infants and young children and is a leading cause of acquired heart disease (coronary artery aneurysms).

symptoms.details: The tongue becomes very red, swollen, and bumpy.
High fever lasting more than 5 days that does not respond to standard fever reducers.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Essential to monitor for the development of coronary artery aneurysms.
Diagnosis is based on specific signs (CRASH and Burn: Conjunctivitis, Rash, Adenopathy, Strawberry tongue, Hands/feet swelling, Fever).

treatments_and_cures.details: Reduces inflammation and significantly lowers the risk of coronary artery damage if given within the first 10 days.
Used for anti-inflammatory and anti-platelet effects (one of the few exceptions for aspirin use in children).

description: An inflammation of the lining of the arteries (ICD-10: M31.5). Most often it affects the arteries in the head, especially those in the temples. It is a medical emergency due to risk of blindness.

symptoms.details: Tenderness over the temples/scalp (pain when brushing hair).
Pain in the jaw when chewing.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Removing a small piece of the artery to look for giant cells under a microscope.
Markers of inflammation that are almost always significantly elevated.

treatments_and_cures.details: Prednisone is started immediately (even before biopsy confirmation) to prevent permanent vision loss.

description: A chronic heart condition caused by the parasite *Trypanosoma cruzi* (Chagas disease) (ICD-10: B57.2). Years after infection, the parasite destroys heart muscle, leading to dilation and failure.

symptoms.details: Edema, fatigue, and dyspnea appearing decades after the insect bite.
Thinning of the tip of the heart, a hallmark of Chagas.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Detects exposure to the parasite.
Often shows a characteristic aneurysm at the apex of the left ventricle.

treatments_and_cures.details: Effective in the acute phase but controversial in the chronic heart failure stage.
Commonly needed due to severe conduction blocks caused by the parasite.

description: A rare type of vasculitis that damages the aorta and its main branches (ICD-10: M31.4). It leads to narrowing or blockage of arteries, often called 'Pulseless Disease'.

symptoms.details: Difficulty feeling a pulse in the arms.
Pain in the arms during activity due to reduced blood flow.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows narrowing, occlusion, or aneurysms in the aorta and large vessels.

treatments_and_cures.details: Drugs like Methotrexate to control the immune system inflammation.
Required if an artery becomes critically blocked, but only performed when inflammation is controlled.

description: Sudden cardiac arrest caused by a blunt impact to the chest (like a baseball or hockey puck) at a precise moment in the heart's electrical cycle (ICD-10: S26.91). It happens without structural damage to the heart.

symptoms.details: Occurs instantaneously after the impact.
The impact triggers chaotic electrical activity.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Confirmed by witnessing the event and finding no structural damage on autopsy or imaging.

treatments_and_cures.details: Survival depends entirely on how quickly an AED is used (within minutes).

description: A temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke (ICD-10: G45.9). A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage, but is a major warning sign of an impending stroke.

symptoms.details: Typically on one side of the body, resolving fully within 24 hours.
Temporary difficulty speaking or understanding.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: To confirm there is NO permanent tissue death (infarction), distinguishing TIA from stroke.
checks for plaque in the neck arteries that may have thrown the clot.

treatments_and_cures.details: Started immediately to prevent a full stroke.
Surgery to clean out the carotid artery if it is significantly narrowed.

description: Bleeding into the space between the brain and the surrounding membrane (ICD-10: I60.9). It is usually caused by a ruptured berry aneurysm.

symptoms.details: Sudden onset of the 'worst headache of life'.
Extreme sensitivity to light.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows fresh blood (white) in the cisterns/sulci of the brain.
Used if CT is negative; detects xanthochromia (yellow spinal fluid from broken down blood).

treatments_and_cures.details: Securing the aneurysm to prevent re-bleeding.
A calcium channel blocker used specifically to prevent vasospasm in brain arteries after the bleed.

description: A complication of tertiary syphilis where the bacteria infect the aorta (ICD-10: A52.0). It causes a 'tree bark' appearance of the aorta and can lead to aneurysms or aortic regurgitation.

symptoms.details: Due to aneurysm expansion or compression of surrounding structures.
Visible on X-ray in the ascending aorta.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Serologic tests to confirm history of syphilis infection.

treatments_and_cures.details: High-dose antibiotics to kill the bacteria, though it cannot reverse existing structural damage.
Surgery required if the aneurysm becomes large or the valve fails.

description: Obstruction of blood flow through the SVC (the vein carrying blood from the head to the heart) (ICD-10: I87.1). It is most commonly caused by lung cancer compressing the vein.

symptoms.details: Swelling of the face, neck, and arms, often worse in the morning.
Visible collateral veins across the chest trying to bypass the blockage.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Identifies the location of the blockage and the underlying cause (mass/thrombus).

treatments_and_cures.details: Placing a stent in the vein to open it up and provide immediate relief.
To shrink the tumor compressing the vein.

description: Bruising of the heart muscle caused by blunt trauma, such as a steering wheel impact in a car accident (ICD-10: S26.0). It can cause cell death similar to a heart attack.

symptoms.details: Pain unrelated to rib fractures, often persistent.
Irregular heartbeats caused by trauma to the conduction system.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Elevated enzymes indicate heart muscle injury.
Shows wall motion abnormalities in the bruised area.

treatments_and_cures.details: Observation for 24-48 hours to treat any arrhythmias that arise.
Pain management to ensure the patient can breathe deeply.

description: Gnarled, enlarged veins, most commonly appearing in the legs and feet (ICD-10: I83.9). They occur when the valves in the veins become weak or damaged, allowing blood to pool backward.

symptoms.details: Veins that are dark purple or blue and appear twisted and bulging like cords.
An achy or heavy feeling in the legs, often worse after standing for a long time.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes the blood flow in the veins and identifies incompetent valves (reflux).

treatments_and_cures.details: Using heat (laser or radiofrequency) to seal the affected vein shut.
Squeezes the legs to help veins and leg muscles move blood more efficiently.

description: A long-term condition where the veins in the leg cannot pump enough blood back to the heart (ICD-10: I87.2). It is a progression of valve damage often leading to skin changes.

symptoms.details: Open sores usually near the ankle that are difficult to heal.
Brownish discoloration of the skin on the lower legs (hemosiderin staining).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Maps the deep and superficial venous systems to locate reflux.
Performed to rule out arterial disease before applying compression therapy.

treatments_and_cures.details: Raising legs above heart level to use gravity to drain the blood.
Surgical removal of the damaged vein (saphenous vein) in severe cases.

description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue (ICD-10: Q87.4). The most dangerous complication is weakness of the aorta, leading to aneurysm or dissection.

symptoms.details: Tall and thin build with disproportionately long arms, legs, and fingers (arachnodactyly).
The lens of the eye shifts out of place (ectopia lentis).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Identifies the mutation in the Fibrillin-1 gene.
Measures the diameter of the aortic root (Z-score).

treatments_and_cures.details: Slows the growth of the aortic aneurysm by reducing hemodynamic stress.
Surgery performed when the aorta reaches 5.0 cm to prevent rupture.

description: Swelling that generally occurs in one of the arms or legs (ICD-10: I89.0). It is caused by a blockage in the lymphatic system, often after cancer surgery or radiation.

symptoms.details: Persistent swelling in one limb that may include the fingers or toes.
Hardening and thickening of the skin in the affected area.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Nuclear medicine imaging to visualize the flow of lymph fluid and blockages.

treatments_and_cures.details: A combination of manual lymph drainage massage, bandaging, and exercise.
Sleeves or stockings worn daily to prevent fluid re-accumulation.

description: Inflammation and clotting in a vein just under the skin (ICD-10: I80.0). Unlike DVT, it rarely causes serious complications like pulmonary embolism.

symptoms.details: The vein feels like a hard, tender cord under the skin.
Localized erythema tracking along the path of the vein.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Usually diagnosed clinically by the appearance and feel of the vein.
Used to ensure the clot does not extend into the deep venous system.

treatments_and_cures.details: Reduces inflammation and pain while the body breaks down the clot naturally.

description: A rare disease of the arteries and veins in the arms and legs (ICD-10: I73.1). Blood vessels become inflamed, swell, and can become blocked with clots. It is strongly linked to tobacco use.

symptoms.details: Tissue death (blackening) of the fingertips or toes.
Pain in the arch of the foot or palm of the hand during activity.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows 'corkscrew' collateral vessels bypassing the occlusions.
Bedside test showing delayed blood flow return to the hand.

treatments_and_cures.details: The only effective way to stop the disease progression. Even one cigarette can trigger a flare.

description: A congenital heart defect where the tricuspid valve sits lower than normal in the right ventricle (ICD-10: Q22.5). This makes the right atrium large and the ventricle small.

symptoms.details: Blue skin coloration if there is a right-to-left shunt (hole) present.
Fast heartbeats are very common due to accessory electrical pathways.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows the apical displacement of the septal tricuspid leaflet.

treatments_and_cures.details: A specialized surgery to reshape the patient's own tissues into a functioning valve.

description: A long-term complication of an uncorrected congenital heart defect (like VSD) (ICD-10: I27.8). High blood flow eventually causes severe pulmonary hypertension, reversing the shunt from left-to-right to right-to-left.

symptoms.details: Permanent blue tint to skin due to oxygen-poor blood mixing into the system.
Rounding and enlargement of the fingertips and nails.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Confirms irreversible pulmonary vascular disease (high resistance).

treatments_and_cures.details: The only cure once the pulmonary vasculature is permanently damaged.
Meds to lower lung pressure and improve quality of life.

description: A severe congenital defect where the left side of the heart is critically underdeveloped (ICD-10: Q23.4). The heart cannot pump oxygen-rich blood to the body effectively.

symptoms.details: Cold, clammy skin, weak pulse, and rapid breathing shortly after the ductus arteriosus closes.
Grayish or blue skin tone indicating poor perfusion.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Diagnosed prenatally by seeing the small left ventricle and aorta.

treatments_and_cures.details: First of three open-heart surgeries to reconstruct the aorta and make the right ventricle pump to the body.
The final surgery (around age 2-3) to separate oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor blood.

description: A genetic disorder of connective tissue caused by defects in collagen (Type IV) (ICD-10: Q79.6). It is the most severe form, causing fragile arteries and organs that are prone to rupture.

symptoms.details: Veins are clearly visible through the skin, particularly on the chest.
Severe bruising without significant trauma.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Confirms the mutation in the type III procollagen gene.

treatments_and_cures.details: A specific beta-blocker shown to reduce the rate of arterial rupture.
Non-invasive imaging to check for aneurysms, avoiding invasive procedures which can tear vessels.

description: A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness (ICD-10: G40.9).

symptoms.details: Loss of consciousness followed by muscle stiffening (tonic) and jerking (clonic).
A warning sensation (smell, dj vu, or visual disturbance) occurring before a seizure.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Records electrical activity of the brain to detect spike-and-wave patterns characteristic of seizures.
Used to find structural causes like tumors or scar tissue (sclerosis).

treatments_and_cures.details: Medications like Levetiracetam or Lamotrigine stabilize electrical activity.
Removing the specific area of the brain generating the seizures (focal resection) if meds fail.

description: An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers (ICD-10: G35). This causes communication problems between the brain and the body.

symptoms.details: Painful vision loss in one eye, often the first symptom.
An electric shock sensation that runs down the neck and back when bending the neck forward.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows active lesions (plaques) appearing as bright spots.
Detects oligoclonal bands (proteins) in the spinal fluid.

treatments_and_cures.details: High-efficacy infusion therapy to prevent relapses and slow progression.
Used acutely to shorten the duration of a flare-up.

description: A progressive disorder that affects the nervous system and the parts of the body controlled by the nerves (ICD-10: G20). It is caused by a loss of neurons that produce dopamine.

symptoms.details: Shaking that occurs when the hand is relaxed ('pill-rolling tremor').
Slowness of movement and loss of automatic movements (like blinking or swinging arms).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Imaging that visualizes the dopamine system in the brain to confirm degeneration.
Significant improvement in symptoms after taking medication supports the diagnosis.

treatments_and_cures.details: The most effective drug; the body converts it into dopamine to replace what is lost.
Surgical implantation of electrodes to regulate abnormal brain impulses.

description: A progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control (ICD-10: G12.21). Often called Lou Gehrig's disease.

symptoms.details: Often starts in hands (dropping things) or feet (tripping), spreading to the rest of the body.
Persistent muscle twitching, visible under the skin.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Detects electrical activity of muscles; shows widespread denervation.

treatments_and_cures.details: Can extend survival by a few months but does not reverse damage.
Helps with breathing as diaphragm muscles weaken, improving quality of life.

description: A serious infection of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding the brain and spinal cord (ICD-10: G00.9). It is a medical emergency.

symptoms.details: Stiff neck; inability to touch chin to chest.
Painful sensitivity to light and loud noises.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows low glucose, high protein, and high white blood cell count in spinal fluid.
Physical exam sign: lifting the head causes knees to flex involuntarily.

treatments_and_cures.details: Started immediately, often before confirmatory tests, to prevent death or brain damage.
Steroid given to reduce brain swelling and hearing loss complications.

description: A neurological condition characterized by intense, debilitating headaches (ICD-10: G43.9). It involves abnormal brain activity affecting nerve signals, chemicals, and blood vessels.

symptoms.details: Throbbing pain usually confined to one side of the head.
Subtle changes 1-2 days before the attack, such as mood swings or food cravings.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Diagnosis is based on the pattern of attacks (at least 5 attacks lasting 4-72 hours).

treatments_and_cures.details: Abortive medication taken at onset to block pain pathways.
Newer class of drugs (monoclonal antibodies) that prevent migraines by blocking a specific protein.

description: A rare disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves (ICD-10: G61.0). Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms.

symptoms.details: Weakness starting in the feet and legs and spreading to the upper body and arms.
Total loss of deep tendon reflexes (e.g., knee jerk).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows 'albuminocytologic dissociation' (high protein with normal cell count).
Shows slowing of nerve signals indicating demyelination.

treatments_and_cures.details: Filtering the blood to remove the antibodies attacking the nerves.
Intravenous immunoglobulin to block the damaging antibodies.

description: A rare, inherited disease that causes the progressive breakdown (degeneration) of nerve cells in the brain (ICD-10: G10). It has a broad impact on functional abilities.

symptoms.details: Involuntary jerking or writhing movements.
Difficulty focusing, impulsivity, and lack of awareness of one's own behaviors.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Counts the CAG repeats in the HTT gene. >40 repeats confirms the disease.

treatments_and_cures.details: Suppresses the involuntary jerking and writhing movements (chorea).
Essential for managing the behavioral and communication decline.

description: Bleeding within the brain tissue itself, usually caused by uncontrolled high blood pressure (ICD-10: I61.9). It is more deadly than ischemic stroke.

symptoms.details: Drowsiness progressing to coma as pressure in the skull increases.
Common sign of increased intracranial pressure (ICP).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Immediately shows bright white area (blood) in the brain tissue.

treatments_and_cures.details: IV meds (Nicardipine) to rapidly lower BP and prevent the bleed from growing.
Removing the blood clot (hematoma) or part of the skull to relieve pressure if life-threatening.

description: An accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that causes the ventricles in the brain to enlarge (ICD-10: G91.2). It typically affects older adults.

symptoms.details: Gait disturbance (magnetic gait), urinary incontinence, and dementia/confusion.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows enlarged ventricles out of proportion to brain atrophy.
Removing 30-50ml of CSF to see if symptoms (walking) temporarily improve.

treatments_and_cures.details: Surgically placing a tube to drain excess fluid from the brain to the abdomen. Often reverses symptoms.

description: An infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus (ICD-10: J15.9). It is acquired outside of a hospital setting.

symptoms.details: Coughing up phlegm (sputum) that may be green, yellow, or bloody.
Sharp chest pain that worsens when breathing deeply or coughing.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows 'consolidation' (white patches) where the air sacs are filled with fluid.
Identifies the specific bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae) to guide antibiotic choice.

treatments_and_cures.details: Empiric therapy is started immediately to kill the bacteria.
Medications like Acetaminophen to manage fever and muscle pain.

description: A sleep disorder where throat muscles intermittently relax and block the airway during sleep (ICD-10: G47.33). It causes breathing to repeatedly stop and start.

symptoms.details: Often punctuated by gasping or choking sounds.
Falling asleep during routine activities due to fragmented sleep architecture.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Records brain waves, oxygen levels, and heart rate during sleep to count apnea events (AHI score).

treatments_and_cures.details: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure machine delivers air pressure to keep the airway open.
Reducing neck circumference can significantly decrease the severity of obstruction.

description: A genetic disorder that affects the cells that produce mucus, sweat, and digestive juices (ICD-10: E84.0). These secreted fluids become thick and sticky, plugging up tubes, ducts, and passageways, especially in the lungs.

symptoms.details: Parents often taste salt when kissing the child's skin.
Greasy, bulky stools due to blocked pancreatic enzymes preventing fat digestion.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Measures the concentration of salt in sweat; high levels confirm the diagnosis.
Identifies specific mutations (e.g., Delta F508) to guide targeted therapy.

treatments_and_cures.details: Drugs that help the defective protein function more effectively, transforming prognosis.
Vibrating vests or manual percussion to help loosen and cough up thick mucus.

description: A chronic disease where the tissue deep in the lungs becomes thick and stiff (scarred) for unknown reasons (ICD-10: J84.112). This makes it harder for the lungs to work and get oxygen into the bloodstream.

symptoms.details: A persistent cough that does not produce mucus.
Widening and rounding of the tips of the fingers and toes due to chronic low oxygen.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows a characteristic 'honeycombing' pattern in the lungs, often avoiding the need for biopsy.
Shows a 'restrictive' pattern (reduced lung volume) with low diffusion capacity (DLCO).

treatments_and_cures.details: Slows the rate of lung function decline but does not reverse scarring.
The only option to restore lung function in advanced disease.

description: A collapsed lung (ICD-10: J93.9). It occurs when air leaks into the space between the lung and the chest wall, pushing on the lung and making it collapse.

symptoms.details: Sharp pain on one side of the chest.
A doctor cannot hear air moving in the affected side with a stethoscope.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows the edge of the collapsed lung and air in the pleural space.

treatments_and_cures.details: Inserting a tube to suck the air out and allow the lung to re-expand.
Small pneumothoraces often heal on their own with supplemental oxygen.

description: The most common type of lung cancer (ICD-10: C34.9). It originates in the bronchial tubes or lung tissue. Smoking is the primary risk factor.

symptoms.details: Coughing up blood or rust-colored sputum.
Loss of appetite and muscle mass.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Taking a tissue sample to confirm cancer cells and determine the specific type.
Used to stage the cancer by checking if it has spread (metastasized) to other parts of the body.

treatments_and_cures.details: Surgical removal of the affected lobe of the lung, curative in early stages.
Uses the body's immune system to attack cancer cells, especially those with high PD-L1 expression.

description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells (granulomas) in any part of the body, most commonly the lungs and lymph nodes (ICD-10: D86.0).

symptoms.details: Persistent cough without phlegm.
Painful, red bumps on the shins, often an early sign.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Reveals 'non-caseating granulomas' (distinct from TB).
Shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (enlarged lymph nodes in the center of the chest).

treatments_and_cures.details: The main treatment to suppress the immune system and reduce granuloma formation.
Many cases resolve spontaneously without medication.

description: A condition where the lungs' airways become permanently damaged, widened, and thickened (ICD-10: J47). Bacteria and mucus build up and pool in these pockets, leading to frequent infections.

symptoms.details: Produces large amounts of thick, foul-smelling sputum.
Frequent bouts of pneumonia requiring antibiotics.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows the airways are wider than the accompanying blood vessels ('signet ring' sign).

treatments_and_cures.details: Devices (like Acapella) or percussion to physically mobilize the mucus.
Long-term use of macrolides to reduce inflammation and infection frequency.

description: A rapidly progressive disease occurring in critically ill patients (ICD-10: J80). Fluid leaks into the lungs' tiny elastic air sacs, preventing oxygen from getting into the blood.

symptoms.details: Extreme difficulty breathing appearing within hours to days of an injury or infection.
Dangerously low oxygen levels that do not improve with standard oxygen therapy.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows widespread 'white-out' of both lungs (bilateral opacities).
PaO2/FiO2 ratio < 300 mmHg confirms the diagnosis (Berlin Criteria).

treatments_and_cures.details: Using low tidal volumes to protect the lungs while they heal.
Flipping the patient onto their stomach to improve oxygenation.

description: A viral infection of the upper airway that obstructs breathing and causes a characteristic cough (ICD-10: J05.0). It primarily affects young children.

symptoms.details: A cough that sounds like a seal barking.
A high-pitched whistling sound when breathing in (inspiration).

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: May show the 'steeple sign' (narrowing of the trachea), though diagnosis is usually clinical.

treatments_and_cures.details: A single dose of steroid reduces swelling in the airway.
Used in severe cases to quickly shrink swollen tissue and improve breathing.

description: Open sores that develop on the inside lining of the stomach and the upper portion of the small intestine (ICD-10: K27). The most common causes are H. pylori infection and long-term use of aspirin/NSAIDs.

symptoms.details: Pain is often felt between meals or at night; eating may briefly relieve it (duodenal) or worsen it (gastric).
Black, tarry stools indicating bleeding from the upper GI tract.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes the ulcer and allows for biopsy to test for cancer or bacteria.
Non-invasive test specifically for detecting active H. pylori infection.

treatments_and_cures.details: A combination of two antibiotics (e.g., Clarithromycin, Amoxicillin) and a PPI to kill the bacteria.
Reduces stomach acid to allow the sore to heal.

description: A type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes inflammation of the digestive tract (ICD-10: K50). Unlike Ulcerative Colitis, it can affect any part of the GI tract and penetrates deep into the tissue layers.

symptoms.details: Often in the lower right quadrant (ileum).
Persistent loose stools, sometimes mixed with blood or mucus.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows 'skip lesions' (patches of disease next to healthy tissue) and granulomas.
Visualizes the small bowel which is hard to reach with endoscopy.

treatments_and_cures.details: Antibodies that target TNF-alpha to reduce inflammation and induce remission.
Surgery to remove damaged sections, though disease often recurs elsewhere.

description: Late-stage scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases, such as hepatitis and chronic alcoholism (ICD-10: K74.60). The liver cannot function or heal itself.

symptoms.details: Accumulation of fluid in the abdomen making it distended.
Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to bilirubin buildup.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Examination of tissue to confirm the extent of scarring.
Ultrasound-based test to measure liver stiffness (fibrosis) non-invasively.

treatments_and_cures.details: The only cure for end-stage liver failure.
Reduces ammonia levels in the blood to prevent confusion (encephalopathy).

description: Hardened deposits of digestive fluid (cholesterol or bilirubin) that can form in the gallbladder (ICD-10: K80). Pain occurs if they block the bile ducts.

symptoms.details: Sudden, intense pain in the upper right abdomen, often after a fatty meal.
Pain radiating to the right shoulder blade.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes stones in the gallbladder and any thickening of the wall.
Nuclear scan to check gallbladder ejection fraction if ultrasound is unclear.

treatments_and_cures.details: Surgical removal of the gallbladder. One of the most common surgeries performed.
Medication to dissolve small cholesterol stones, used only if surgery isn't an option.

description: Sudden inflammation of the pancreas (ICD-10: K85). Digestive enzymes become active while still inside the pancreas, irritating the cells and causing inflammation.

symptoms.details: Severe upper abdominal pain that radiates straight through to the back.
Vomiting that does not relieve the pain.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Levels >3x normal limit are diagnostic.
Shows swelling of the pancreas and fluid around it.

treatments_and_cures.details: Stopping solid food intake to stop the pancreas from producing enzymes.
Critical to prevent hypovolemic shock and kidney failure.

description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye (ICD-10: K90.0). Over time, the immune reaction damages the small intestine's lining (villi).

symptoms.details: Abdominal distension after eating gluten.
Itchy, blistering skin rash usually on elbows/knees.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows villous atrophy (flattening of the finger-like projections in the gut).
Screening blood test for tissue transglutaminase antibodies.

treatments_and_cures.details: Strict lifelong avoidance of gluten allows the intestine to heal completely.

description: An autoimmune disorder affecting the thyroid gland (ICD-10: E06.3). The immune system attacks the thyroid, leading to hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid).

symptoms.details: Sluggishness and feeling cold all the time.
Unexplained weight gain or difficulty losing weight.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Detects thyroid peroxidase antibodies, the hallmark of Hashimoto's.
Elevated TSH indicates the pituitary is trying to stimulate a failing thyroid.

treatments_and_cures.details: Synthetic hormone replacement taken daily.

description: An immune system disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism) (ICD-10: E05.0).

symptoms.details: Bulging eyes caused by inflammation of the muscles behind the eye.
Fine trembling in hands and feeling jittery.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Detects thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins.
Shows high, diffuse uptake of iodine by the gland.

treatments_and_cures.details: Destroys the overactive thyroid cells; usually leads to permanent hypothyroidism.
Controls the rapid heart rate and tremors.

description: A disorder where the adrenal glands produce insufficient amounts of the hormones cortisol and aldosterone (ICD-10: E27.1).

symptoms.details: Darkening of the skin, especially in creases and gums.
Due to low aldosterone and sodium loss.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Measures cortisol response to synthetic ACTH injection. No rise indicates Addison's.

treatments_and_cures.details: Lifelong replacement of the missing steroid hormones.

description: A condition that occurs from exposure to high cortisol levels for a long time (ICD-10: E24.9). It can be caused by tumors or long-term steroid medication use.

symptoms.details: Face becomes round and full.
Fat pad accumulation between the shoulders.
Wide, reddish-purple stretch marks on the abdomen.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Taking a steroid pill at night and measuring cortisol in the morning. Failure to lower cortisol indicates Cushing's.
Measures total cortisol production over a full day.

treatments_and_cures.details: Removal of the pituitary tumor if that is the cause (Cushing's Disease).
Medication that inhibits cortisol production.

description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells (ICD-10: C91.0). It progresses rapidly and creates immature blood cells rather than mature ones.

symptoms.details: Due to low platelet counts (thrombocytopenia) as cancer cells crowd out normal marrow.
The white blood cells produced are abnormal and cannot fight infection.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Shows hypercellular marrow with >20% blasts (immature cells).
Shows anemia, low platelets, and often very high white cell counts.

treatments_and_cures.details: Aggressive drug regimens (e.g., Vincristine, Prednisone) to kill leukemia cells and restore normal blood production.
Replacing diseased bone marrow with healthy stem cells from a donor.

description: Cancer that occurs in the prostate, a small walnut-shaped gland in men (ICD-10: C61). It is one of the most common types of cancer.

symptoms.details: Difficulty starting urination or a weak flow due to the tumor pressing on the urethra.
Blood in the urine or semen.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Taking tissue samples to determine the Gleason Score (aggressiveness).
Blood test used for screening; elevated levels suggest cancer or inflammation.

treatments_and_cures.details: Surgical removal of the entire prostate gland.
Hormone therapy to lower testosterone, which feeds the cancer.

description: Cancer that starts in the colon or rectum (ICD-10: C18-C20). It usually begins as small, noncancerous clumps of cells called polyps.

symptoms.details: Persistent diarrhea, constipation, or narrowing of the stool.
Bright red blood in stool or dark, tarry stools.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visual inspection of the entire colon with the ability to remove polyps or biopsy masses.
Tumor marker blood test used to monitor response to treatment.

treatments_and_cures.details: Surgical removal of the cancer and a margin of healthy tissue.
Removing polyps during colonoscopy prevents them from turning into cancer.

description: The most common type of kidney cancer in adults (ICD-10: C64). It originates in the lining of the small tubes (tubules) in the kidney.

symptoms.details: Pain in the side or back that doesn't go away.
Blood in the urine, which may appear pink, red, or cola-colored.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Multi-phase imaging to distinguish solid masses from cysts.

treatments_and_cures.details: Surgical removal of the kidney (radical) or just the tumor (partial).
Drugs like Sunitinib that block blood vessel growth (angiogenesis) in the tumor.

description: Gradual loss of kidney function over time (ICD-10: N18.9). Common causes are diabetes and high blood pressure. Wastes build up in the body.

symptoms.details: Swelling in feet and ankles due to inability to remove fluid.
Severe itching caused by high levels of phosphorus in the blood.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Calculated from blood creatinine; determines the stage of kidney disease (1-5).
Detects protein in the urine, an early sign of kidney damage.

treatments_and_cures.details: Lowers pressure inside the kidney filters to slow progression.
Filtering blood via a machine (Hemodialysis) when kidneys fail (ESRD).

description: Hard deposits made of minerals and salts that form inside the kidneys (ICD-10: N20.0). Passing them can be extremely painful.

symptoms.details: Severe, fluctuating pain in the side and back, radiating to the groin.
Persistent need to urinate if the stone is in the lower ureter.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Detects almost all types of stones (calcium, uric acid, etc.).

treatments_and_cures.details: Using sound waves to break stones into tiny pieces.
Relaxes the ureter muscle to help pass the stone more easily.

description: An inherited disorder where clusters of cysts develop primarily within the kidneys (ICD-10: Q61.3). The cysts cause kidneys to enlarge and lose function over time.

symptoms.details: High blood pressure is often the first sign.
Visible enlargement of the abdomen due to massive kidney size.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Visualizes multiple cysts in both kidneys.
Confirms the specific gene mutation.

treatments_and_cures.details: Slows cyst growth and decline in kidney function.
Required once end-stage renal failure is reached.

description: A cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell (ICD-10: C90.0). Cancerous plasma cells accumulate in the bone marrow and crowd out healthy blood cells.

symptoms.details: Pain in the spine or chest; lytic lesions cause weak bones that break easily.
High calcium levels causing thirst, nausea, and confusion.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Detects the 'M spike' (monoclonal protein) produced by the cancer cells.
Identifies 'punched-out' lytic lesions in the bones.

treatments_and_cures.details: Drugs that cause cancer cells to die by preventing them from breaking down proteins.
Strengthens bones to prevent fractures.

description: A cancer of the lymphatic system (ICD-10: C81). It is distinguished from other lymphomas by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

symptoms.details: Swollen lymph nodes in the neck, armpits, or groin that are not painful.
Fever, night sweats, and unexplained weight loss.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: Required to see the architecture of the node and identify Reed-Sternberg cells.
Shows metabolic activity to stage the disease (Stage I-IV).

treatments_and_cures.details: A standard combination regimen (Adriamycin, Bleomycin, Vinblastine, Dacarbazine) with high cure rates.

description: A sudden episode of kidney failure or kidney damage that happens within a few hours or a few days (ICD-10: N17.9). Causes include dehydration, blood loss, or toxins.

symptoms.details: Decreased urine output.
Swelling in legs/ankles due to inability to excrete water.

diagnostic_procedures.purpose: A rapid rise in creatinine (e.g., >0.3 mg/dL in 48 hours) confirms AKI.
Checks for muddy brown casts (sign of acute tubular necrosis).

treatments_and_cures.details: Restores blood flow to the kidneys in pre-renal causes (dehydration).
Stopping drugs like NSAIDs or certain antibiotics to allow kidneys to recover.
